<div class="mck-o-sidebar mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Ftravel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure%2Four%20insights%2Fdigitizing%20mid%20and%20last%20mile%20logistics%20handovers%20to%20reduce%20waste%2Fdigitizing-mid-and-last-mile-logistics-handovers-to-reduce-waste.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Article" data-layer-file-name="digitizing-mid-and-last-mile-logistics-handovers-to-reduce-waste" data-layer-report-name="digitizing-mid-and-last-mile-logistics-handovers-to-reduce-waste>Article"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Article (9 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div></div>

<p><strong>Even in a well-oiled logistics chain,</strong> there can be significant waste. Much of it occurs around what can be called “blind handoffs”—when two (or more) parties are involved in the handover of goods on their journey between manufacturers, warehouses, retail stores, and consumers’ homes. These points are where costly miscommunication, loss of information, and delays are most likely to happen. McKinsey analysis finds that between 13 and 19 percent of logistics costs could stem from these inefficient interactions, amounting to up to $95 billion in losses a year—in the United States economy alone.</p>
<p>Until now, the most common approach taken by shippers and carriers to reduce waste has been to increase visibility across their logistics chains by adopting real-time transportation visibility platforms (RTTVP). The market for these solutions has expanded rapidly; startups offering visibility solutions have attracted around $7 billion in funding since 2022.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d4790b1e-2abd-4151-b7ca-45877c989136"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d4790b1e-2abd-4151-b7ca-45877c989136" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of data from: CB Insights; Crunchbase; and Pitchbook.</span></span></span></a></span> This gives some sense of the industry’s appetite for waste reduction. While visibility is essential, perhaps more can be done to address the handover points where waste happens, for instance by finding ways to make coordination and communication seamless when goods need to change hands.</p>
<p>Technology companies, shippers, and carriers have been working to develop software that streamlines coordination and communication. Apart from RTTVP, two other types of solutions have emerged: AI-based workflow automation, and generative AI-driven contextual communication. Our analysis suggests that a combination of these three innovations, implemented appropriately, can reduce waste caused by blind handoffs by up to 40 percent.</p>
<p>Of course, technology alone may not be enough to achieve such a significant reduction. Getting it right will likely require companies to measure the extent of their handover losses, find ways to integrate the relevant solutions within their existing operating models and tech stacks, and build new digital capabilities before they reap the benefits.</p>
<p>Both B2B and B2C carriers stand to benefit the most from addressing blind handoffs, and success stories exist of such companies reducing their operating costs by doing so. This article reviews the three emerging solutions and draws on best practices that can be applied, specifically in middle- and last-mile logistics. It does not address first-mile or intermodal logistics, which are the focus of our ongoing research into other parts of the logistics value chain.</p>
<p>While the research behind this article is specific to the United States, the themes it uncovers are applicable to logistics globally.</p>
<h2>Waste: how it happens, what it costs</h2>
<p>Blind handoffs happen at multiple points across the logistics chain, spanning B2C and B2B deliveries. Based on our research, we estimate that in the US, the value of all middle- and last-mile deliveries of e-commerce, food and beverage, and consumer retail and packaged goods by road came to around $485 billion in 2021 (Exhibit 1).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/digitizing%20mid%20and%20last%20mile%20logistics%20handovers%20to%20reduce%20waste/svgz-blind-handoffs-ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Blind handoffs are when two or more parties are involved in the handover of goods; the US market where these can occur is worth $720 billion." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/digitizing%20mid%20and%20last%20mile%20logistics%20handovers%20to%20reduce%20waste/svgz-blind-handoffs-ex1-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Within this value pool, between $65 billion and $95 billion of waste is generated at interaction points between shippers, dispatchers, third-party logistics companies (3PLs), and carriers at the time of delivery. Most of these losses affect B2B companies, likely between $45 billion and $66 billion a year. Losses for B2C interactions may total $18 billion to $28 billion a year, mainly driven by the costs of dwell time.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f06195a-285c-4f81-99ae-c660e26225e1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f06195a-285c-4f81-99ae-c660e26225e1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis of data from: American Trucking Association; Armstrong & Associates; Bloomberg; Freight Analysis Framework, United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics; Freight Waves; Statista; US Census; and US Department of Transportation (Bureau of Transportation Statistics).</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Waste is made up of direct and indirect costs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a9f7488b-8db5-4761-be5c-cf6e5d349a40"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a9f7488b-8db5-4761-be5c-cf6e5d349a40" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Figures on the costs associated with blind handoffs are the result of McKinsey analysis of data from the following sources: “Ranking of ecom product brands in the US in 2022,” Affinity Solutions; “2022 Annual report ,” Amazon; “Comparing The Cost Of Shipping Insurance,” Cabrella shipping insurance, July 2, 2019; “2023 U.S. B2B E-commerce market report,” Digitalcommerce360, February, 2023; Freight Analysis Framework, United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics, August 28, 2023; Statista; “More than 1 in 10 packages 'disappear without explanation' in major US cities, and it's a huge headache for retailers”, <em>Business Insider</em>, Dec 3, 2019; <em>The final 50 feet urban goods delivery system: Common carrier locker pilot test at the Seattle municipal tower</em>, University of Washington Supply Chain and Logistics Center, October 2018; John Gallagher, “Are drivers wait times nullifying carrier pay increases?” FreightWaves, October 20, 2021; “Dock delays and detention are a big issue,” Trinity Logistics, November 17, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Direct costs include:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Communication.</strong> For B2C carriers, direct communication costs account for up to 0.5 percent of revenue. Losses are accrued through the roughly 6,000 customer service agents in the US who are fully dedicated to logistics issues.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="55d07b8b-69f7-423b-9fd8-78cc2a28a2e1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="55d07b8b-69f7-423b-9fd8-78cc2a28a2e1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming total number of customer service representatives in consumer goods companies in US is roughly 430,000; 1–2 percent of customer service representatives are fully dedicated to logistics issues, including scheduling, route optimization, and delivery problems escalation.</span></span></span></a></span> Around 70 percent of their time is spent resolving problems caused by blind handoffs. Meanwhile, B2B carriers have around 50,000 dispatchers altogether. Similarly, 70 percent of their time is dedicated to issues caused by blind handoffs.</li>
    <li><strong>Detention or dwell time.</strong> For B2C carriers, this amounts to 3 to 5 percent of revenue. The costs accrue through 160 million hours spent in dwell time per year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bb339bbb-932e-456a-92f0-02f87298bcc4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bb339bbb-932e-456a-92f0-02f87298bcc4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming 0.1 billion shipments per year, 100 stops per truck per day, 10  percent of stops with 12 minutes dwell time.</span></span></span></a></span> Between 1 and 1.5 hours are spent in avoidable dwell time every day.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8d1c964e-ac52-43f4-8706-cc37531ee49d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8d1c964e-ac52-43f4-8706-cc37531ee49d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming 100 stops per truck per day, 10 percent of stops with dwell time of 12 minutes per stop.</span></span></span></a></span> And, in B2B, 850 million hours are spent in detention or dwell time each year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="59482cd2-6832-4a3a-96e3-a41a421fb374"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="59482cd2-6832-4a3a-96e3-a41a421fb374" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Including 0.4 billion hours spent in paid detention time and 0.8 billion hours spent in non-paid dwell time; dwell time is an opportunity loss for 3rd party carriers and accounts for $6 billion revenue losses in the US for logistics providers; including 30 percent reductions for dwell time not related to blind handoffs e.g., paperwork, congestions.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><strong>Lost and stolen packages.</strong> For B2C carriers, 23 billion packages are delivered every year in the US, of which 1.5 percent are lost or stolen in last-mile deliveries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="90aa4b8d-d2e8-4b63-b469-e76a5f29d0c0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="90aa4b8d-d2e8-4b63-b469-e76a5f29d0c0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Around 0.62 billion packages are lost and stolen annually on last mile, assuming 50 percent of losses are due to blind handoffs and that 75 percent of packages are insured for B2C for $0.7 per $100 value.</span></span></span></a></span> In B2B, 0.1 percent of shipments are lost or stolen in middle- and last-mile deliveries in the US.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7ce3b50e-26a2-43b3-8661-5db207bc3770"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7ce3b50e-26a2-43b3-8661-5db207bc3770" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming 100 percent of packages are insured for B2B for $0.7$ per $100 value.</span></span></span></a></span></li>
    <li><strong>Re-deliveries.</strong> For B2C carriers, this accounts for 1 to 3 percent of revenue; 10 percent of packages delivered in last-mile logistics need to be re-delivered.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3dc96b6e-f50a-49b1-90fe-c9c23f8c7ccc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3dc96b6e-f50a-49b1-90fe-c9c23f8c7ccc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Approximately 15 percent of deliveries in the US are subject to re-delivery; assuming 5 percent are related to damaged packages and 10 percent to blind handoffs.</span></span></span></a></span> The cost of re-delivery is negligible in B2B.</li>
</ul>
<p>These issues also lead to indirect costs, specifically from customer dissatisfaction and low re-ordering rates. Customer dissatisfaction tends to spike when customers experience delivery issues. In fact, 88 percent of consumers abandon their online shopping carts due to poor shipping terms, and 85 percent say they will not shop with a retailer again after having a poor delivery experience.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="41f90138-a7be-42bd-bc65-db8c006ee79a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="41f90138-a7be-42bd-bc65-db8c006ee79a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Komal Puri, “The last mile mandate: Key insights from a U.S. consumer survey,” <em>FarEye</em>, October 13, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Other indirect costs include driver dissatisfaction, the environmental impact of fuel wasted during dwell time and re-delivery, and productivity loss through inefficient vehicle use and operational issues in warehouses and processing centers.</p>
<p>Costs impact carriers the most, relative to shippers or any other participant in the value chain (Exhibit 2). All in all, the total cost of waste at blind handoffs likely accounts for between 6 and 13 percent of carriers’ overall revenue.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8ccb4547-1eab-4f3f-81e0-b34eaf7dd9c0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8ccb4547-1eab-4f3f-81e0-b34eaf7dd9c0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Figures are the result of McKinsey analysis of data from the following sources: “Ranking of ecom product brands in the US in 2022,” Affinity Solutions; American Trucking Association; Freight Analysis Framework, United States Bureau of Transportation Statistics; Major market FTL and LTL logistics companies’ annual reports.</span></span></span></a></span> Even if the customer is not directly responsible for any of the costs, they will ultimately bear the burden through price increases and wasted time. Collectively, according to our analysis, US customers could spend hundreds of millions of hours a year tracking misplaced packages.</p>

Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>A successful handoff requires four capabilities: consistent processes with an easy-to-use platform; real-time collaboration and communication; seamless cross-party communication; and minimum personnel time.</p>
<p>However, our work with logistics companies reveals that the most widespread methods for communication and coordination in logistics do not fully address these capabilities. The most common communication method is text messaging back and forth between two parties at a time, resulting in reactive updates for shippers. On the plus side, text messaging incurs relatively low costs which are often subsidized by carriers. However, there is little real-time collaboration and cross-party communication. A notable disadvantage is this method’s high requirement for in-person engagement and its possible impact on driver safety. Its chief advantage is its easy-to-use platform.</p>
<p>The next-most common method is conducting multiple phone calls between two parties at a time, also resulting in reactive updates for shippers. Similar to texting, advantages include relatively low costs and a platform that is easy to use. Disadvantages include the fact that communication can happen between only two parties at a time and that making phone calls could have implications for driver safety.</p>
<p>A more recent method, with less uptake, involves using multiple delivery-management apps to coordinate between parties. These provide real-time updates, giving shippers periodic information through emails or tracking links. This method has low usage and relatively high costs (between $20 and $45 per driver). While the sharing of some information is automated, this method still requires high in-person engagement. It facilitates real-time collaboration, but the platforms are relatively difficult to learn and use, and imperfectly provide for cross-party communication.</p>
<h2>Three software-based innovations can reduce waste</h2>
<p>New and emerging software-based solutions exist that can provide the capabilities needed for successful blind handoffs. Since 2012, these solutions have attracted a collective $12 billion in investments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f5dfd8fe-3a8a-4dfe-b76f-2ef9e011c229"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f5dfd8fe-3a8a-4dfe-b76f-2ef9e011c229" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Figures on the markets for digital innovations are the result of McKinsey analysis of data from: CB Insights; Crunchbase; and Pitchbook.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Real-time transportation visibility platforms</h3>
<p>The chief function of RTTVPs is to provide visibility on logistics. This is done by using Advanced Programming Interface (API) integrations, real-time tracking, and predictive analytics. RTTVPs are facilitated by delivery management platforms, such as applications for drivers to plan and execute deliveries. Key contributions include providing transparency and visibility at every stage of delivery, optimizing previously inefficient routes, and the ability to manage customer expectations by giving them a near real-time view of their shipment’s location at any given time.</p>
<p>Currently, RTTVP is the best-established solution in the market, with 178 companies based in the US that provide such platforms. Analysis indicates that around 80 percent of carriers in the US have adopted some form of RTTVP.</p>
<h3>AI-based workflow automation</h3>
<p>These emerging solutions focus on simplifying complex logistics scheduling and optimizing routing. Some also provide a digital co-pilot for customer service representatives. For example, an AI-based co-pilot could send alerts, address questions, and proactively adjust routes as issues occur.</p>
<p>AI-based workflow automation is newer to the market than RTTVPs, with 53 companies based in the US that provide these solutions. Since 2012, innovations in this category have attracted $2.9 billion in investments.</p>
<h3>Generative AI-driven contextual communication</h3>
<p>These solutions are the most recent disruptive innovation. This category has received $1.7 billion in funding since 2012 and includes 13 US-based companies. These solutions tackle delivery challenges by building contextual understanding around deliveries and involving all parties through real-time simultaneous communication. Key contributions of this technology include understanding context; reducing miscommunication between shippers, carriers, and recipients; providing autonomous agents to improve the efficiency of customer service agents; and reducing manual intervention from drivers and dispatchers which is the current paradigm.</p>

data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The logistics and transportation company, Ryder, achieved major improvements in efficiency and customer satisfaction by investing in tech-based innovations</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Ryder upgraded its technology to provide customers with self-scheduling delivery and real-time visibility and notifications in its RyderView platform. Combined with enhanced business intelligence and analytics, the new system helped to reduce costs while streamlining operations and boosting customer satisfaction.</p>

<p>The company invested in real-time track and trace capabilities to provide visibility on deliveries to all stakeholders, including shippers, carriers, drivers, and end customers. These capabilities are enhanced by self-service scheduling. The new system also enables the sending of notifications—for example, sharing reminders, photos, and other information relevant to deliveries. These innovations have had a tangible impact on Ryder’s operations. The system allows Ryder to project and communicate a two-hour window within which customers could begin to receive packages, making it easier to plan for deliveries. It also provides options for different time windows per day. And customers are showing their appreciation with higher customer ratings.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Several logistics companies are currently using one, or more, of these solutions, and seeing results (see sidebar, “The transport and logistics company, Ryder, achieved major improvements in efficiency and customer satisfaction by investing in tech-based innovations”).</p>
<h2>Combining solutions to increase impact</h2>
<p>The impact of solutions to blind handoffs varies according to the business model of the company adopting them, fleet size, and their specific needs and challenges. While each solution has standalone value, companies could use them in combination to enhance the capabilities they provide—and increase the benefits the company is likely to see.</p>
<p>As RTTVP is the most mature of these innovations, this could be a good place to start for companies setting out on implementing new technology to improve blind handoffs. However, most logistics companies already have some form of RTTVP in place. A McKinsey <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/digital-logistics-technology-race-gathers-momentum">survey of more than 250 logistics firms</a> in May 2023 found that tools supporting real-time visibility and telematics for fleet management have seen above-average adoption and investment rates.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5254f2a8-6c6c-4126-8b0a-d0d2f624de0f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5254f2a8-6c6c-4126-8b0a-d0d2f624de0f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“<a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/digital-logistics-technology-race-gathers-momentum">Digital logistics: Technology race gathers momentum</a>,” McKinsey, November 16, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Once tools that give visibility are in place, companies could complement and enhance their capabilities by using AI to automate some processes and, sequentially or in tandem, use gen AI solutions too, for instance as add-on solutions for drivers. Some visibility companies are moving toward adding these components to the platforms they provide.</p>
<p>For carriers, combining these solutions could reduce direct costs by 35 to 40 percent and reduce indirect costs by 25 to 45 percent (Exhibit 3).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/digitizing%20mid%20and%20last%20mile%20logistics%20handovers%20to%20reduce%20waste/svgz-blind-handoffs-ex3-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Combining all three software innovations may have the greatest impact." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/travel%20logistics%20and%20infrastructure/our%20insights/digitizing%20mid%20and%20last%20mile%20logistics%20handovers%20to%20reduce%20waste/svgz-blind-handoffs-ex3-v2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The tech-based innovations themselves may not be enough to realize maximum value—the technology alone is not a panacea. Appropriate <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-rewired-enterprise-how-five-companies-built-to-outcompete">change-management practices around implementation are indispensable</a> for realizing the potential of tech upgrades.</p>
<p>Carriers and shippers are beginning to adopt these innovations, but there is still value to realize. Companies may struggle to implement these solutions due to a lack of strategic alignment, lack of required capabilities, or insufficient adoption at scale. Companies considering tech adoption could look to these as potential next steps on their journey to reduce waste:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Develop strategic alignment.</strong> This involves an assessment of how much value is at stake and the efficiencies that could be realized through new technology. A key enabler for logistics carriers and shippers may be understanding current operations and then embarking on change management including training personnel and outlining expectations of future operating procedures.</li>
    <li><strong>Achieve adoption at scale.</strong> This may require companies to design and use an implementation roadmap incorporating appropriate change-management practices to guide the tech transformation. A big-bang approach, considering the disparate operations and personnel involved, could be risky. Taking a phased approach, and aligning any changes with the existing operating model, could set tech adoption up to succeed.</li>
    <li><strong>Build capabilities.</strong> Companies can create a tailored approach, accounting for existing complexities unique to their context. Shippers and carriers may consider setting KPIs for milestones and impact such as reduced dwell time for drivers, or improvement in driver experience.</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>The problems caused by blind handoffs are worth solving as they can cost the logistics industry up to $95 billion a year in wasted time and resources. Logistics operators have begun exploring tech-based solutions to these problems resulting in a rapidly expanding market for such solutions.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/dilip-bhattacharjee">Dilip Bhattacharjee</a></strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Chicago office, <strong>Ali Kamil</strong> is an expert associate partner in the Dallas office, <strong>Melissa Lukasiewicz</strong> is a consultant in the Denver office, and <strong>Leo Melnikov</strong> is a partner in the New York office.</p>

1]]\n[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEven in a well-oiled logistics chain,\u003c/strong\u003e there can be significant waste. Much of it occurs around what can be called \u0026ldquo;blind handoffs\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;when two (or more) parties are involved in the handover of goods on their journey between manufacturers, warehouses, retail stores, and consumers\u0026rsquo; homes. These points are where costly miscommunication, loss of information, and delays are most likely to happen. McKinsey analysis finds that between 13 and 19 percent of logistics costs could stem from these inefficient interactions, amounting to up to $95 billion in losses a year\u0026mdash;in the United States economy alone.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUntil now, the most common approach taken by shippers and carriers to reduce waste has been to increase visibility across their logistics chains by adopting real-time transportation visibility platforms (RTTVP). The market for these solutions has expanded rapidly; startups offering visibility solutions have attracted around $7 billion in funding since 2022.[[footnote 1]] This gives some sense of the industry\u0026rsquo;s appetite for waste reduction. While visibility is essential, perhaps more can be done to address the handover points where waste happens, for instance by finding ways to make coordination and communication seamless when goods need to change hands.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTechnology companies, shippers, and carriers have been working to develop software that streamlines coordination and communication. Apart from RTTVP, two other types of solutions have emerged: AI-based workflow automation, and generative AI-driven contextual communication. Our analysis suggests that a combination of these three innovations, implemented appropriately, can reduce waste caused by blind handoffs by up to 40 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOf course, technology alone may not be enough to achieve such a significant reduction. Getting it right will likely require companies to measure the extent of their handover losses, find ways to integrate the relevant solutions within their existing operating models and tech stacks, and build new digital capabilities before they reap the benefits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth B2B and B2C carriers stand to benefit the most from addressing blind handoffs, and success stories exist of such companies reducing their operating costs by doing so. This article reviews the three emerging solutions and draws on best practices that can be applied, specifically in middle- and last-mile logistics. It does not address first-mile or intermodal logistics, which are the focus of our ongoing research into other parts of the logistics value chain.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile the research behind this article is specific to the United States, the themes it uncovers are applicable to logistics globally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eWaste: how it happens, what it costs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBlind handoffs happen at multiple points across the logistics chain, spanning B2C and B2B deliveries. Based on our research, we estimate that in the US, the value of all middle- and last-mile deliveries of e-commerce, food and beverage, and consumer retail and packaged goods by road came to around $485 billion in 2021 (Exhibit 1).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eWithin this value pool, between $65 billion and $95 billion of waste is generated at interaction points between shippers, dispatchers, third-party logistics companies (3PLs), and carriers at the time of delivery. Most of these losses affect B2B companies, likely between $45 billion and $66 billion a year. Losses for B2C interactions may total $18 billion to $28 billion a year, mainly driven by the costs of dwell time.[[footnote 2]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWaste is made up of direct and indirect costs.[[footnote 3]] Direct costs include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCommunication.\u003c/strong\u003e For B2C carriers, direct communication costs account for up to 0.5 percent of revenue. Losses are accrued through the roughly 6,000 customer service agents in the US who are fully dedicated to logistics issues.[[footnote 4]] Around 70 percent of their time is spent resolving problems caused by blind handoffs. Meanwhile, B2B carriers have around 50,000 dispatchers altogether. Similarly, 70 percent of their time is dedicated to issues caused by blind handoffs.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDetention or dwell time.\u003c/strong\u003e For B2C carriers, this amounts to 3 to 5 percent of revenue. The costs accrue through 160 million hours spent in dwell time per year.[[footnote 5]] Between 1 and 1.5 hours are spent in avoidable dwell time every day.[[footnote 6]] And, in B2B, 850 million hours are spent in detention or dwell time each year.[[footnote 7]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eLost and stolen packages.\u003c/strong\u003e For B2C carriers, 23 billion packages are delivered every year in the US, of which 1.5 percent are lost or stolen in last-mile deliveries.[[footnote 8]] In B2B, 0.1 percent of shipments are lost or stolen in middle- and last-mile deliveries in the US.[[footnote 9]]\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRe-deliveries.\u003c/strong\u003e For B2C carriers, this accounts for 1 to 3 percent of revenue; 10 percent of packages delivered in last-mile logistics need to be re-delivered.[[footnote 10]] The cost of re-delivery is negligible in B2B.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese issues also lead to indirect costs, specifically from customer dissatisfaction and low re-ordering rates. Customer dissatisfaction tends to spike when customers experience delivery issues. In fact, 88 percent of consumers abandon their online shopping carts due to poor shipping terms, and 85 percent say they will not shop with a retailer again after having a poor delivery experience.[[footnote 11]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOther indirect costs include driver dissatisfaction, the environmental impact of fuel wasted during dwell time and re-delivery, and productivity loss through inefficient vehicle use and operational issues in warehouses and processing centers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCosts impact carriers the most, relative to shippers or any other participant in the value chain (Exhibit 2). All in all, the total cost of waste at blind handoffs likely accounts for between 6 and 13 percent of carriers\u0026rsquo; overall revenue.[[footnote 12]] Even if the customer is not directly responsible for any of the costs, they will ultimately bear the burden through price increases and wasted time. Collectively, according to our analysis, US customers could spend hundreds of millions of hours a year tracking misplaced packages.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eA successful handoff requires four capabilities: consistent processes with an easy-to-use platform; real-time collaboration and communication; seamless cross-party communication; and minimum personnel time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, our work with logistics companies reveals that the most widespread methods for communication and coordination in logistics do not fully address these capabilities. The most common communication method is text messaging back and forth between two parties at a time, resulting in reactive updates for shippers. On the plus side, text messaging incurs relatively low costs which are often subsidized by carriers. However, there is little real-time collaboration and cross-party communication. A notable disadvantage is this method\u0026rsquo;s high requirement for in-person engagement and its possible impact on driver safety. Its chief advantage is its easy-to-use platform.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe next-most common method is conducting multiple phone calls between two parties at a time, also resulting in reactive updates for shippers. Similar to texting, advantages include relatively low costs and a platform that is easy to use. Disadvantages include the fact that communication can happen between only two parties at a time and that making phone calls could have implications for driver safety.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA more recent method, with less uptake, involves using multiple delivery-management apps to coordinate between parties. These provide real-time updates, giving shippers periodic information through emails or tracking links. This method has low usage and relatively high costs (between $20 and $45 per driver). While the sharing of some information is automated, this method still requires high in-person engagement. It facilitates real-time collaboration, but the platforms are relatively difficult to learn and use, and imperfectly provide for cross-party communication.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eThree software-based innovations can reduce waste\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew and emerging software-based solutions exist that can provide the capabilities needed for successful blind handoffs. Since 2012, these solutions have attracted a collective $12 billion in investments.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReal-time transportation visibility platforms\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe chief function of RTTVPs is to provide visibility on logistics. This is done by using Advanced Programming Interface (API) integrations, real-time tracking, and predictive analytics. RTTVPs are facilitated by delivery management platforms, such as applications for drivers to plan and execute deliveries. Key contributions include providing transparency and visibility at every stage of delivery, optimizing previously inefficient routes, and the ability to manage customer expectations by giving them a near real-time view of their shipment\u0026rsquo;s location at any given time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCurrently, RTTVP is the best-established solution in the market, with 178 companies based in the US that provide such platforms. Analysis indicates that around 80 percent of carriers in the US have adopted some form of RTTVP.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eAI-based workflow automation\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese emerging solutions focus on simplifying complex logistics scheduling and optimizing routing. Some also provide a digital co-pilot for customer service representatives. For example, an AI-based co-pilot could send alerts, address questions, and proactively adjust routes as issues occur.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAI-based workflow automation is newer to the market than RTTVPs, with 53 companies based in the US that provide these solutions. Since 2012, innovations in this category have attracted $2.9 billion in investments.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGenerative AI-driven contextual communication\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese solutions are the most recent disruptive innovation. This category has received $1.7 billion in funding since 2012 and includes 13 US-based companies. These solutions tackle delivery challenges by building contextual understanding around deliveries and involving all parties through real-time simultaneous communication. Key contributions of this technology include understanding context; reducing miscommunication between shippers, carriers, and recipients; providing autonomous agents to improve the efficiency of customer service agents; and reducing manual intervention from drivers and dispatchers which is the current paradigm.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral logistics companies are currently using one, or more, of these solutions, and seeing results (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;The transport and logistics company, Ryder, achieved major improvements in efficiency and customer satisfaction by investing in tech-based innovations\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCombining solutions to increase impact\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe impact of solutions to blind handoffs varies according to the business model of the company adopting them, fleet size, and their specific needs and challenges. While each solution has standalone value, companies could use them in combination to enhance the capabilities they provide\u0026mdash;and increase the benefits the company is likely to see.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs RTTVP is the most mature of these innovations, this could be a good place to start for companies setting out on implementing new technology to improve blind handoffs. However, most logistics companies already have some form of RTTVP in place. A McKinsey \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/digital-logistics-technology-race-gathers-momentum\"\u003esurvey of more than 250 logistics firms\u003c/a\u003e in May 2023 found that tools supporting real-time visibility and telematics for fleet management have seen above-average adoption and investment rates.[[footnote 14]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOnce tools that give visibility are in place, companies could complement and enhance their capabilities by using AI to automate some processes and, sequentially or in tandem, use gen AI solutions too, for instance as add-on solutions for drivers. Some visibility companies are moving toward adding these components to the platforms they provide.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor carriers, combining these solutions could reduce direct costs by 35 to 40 percent and reduce indirect costs by 25 to 45 percent (Exhibit 3).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe tech-based innovations themselves may not be enough to realize maximum value\u0026mdash;the technology alone is not a panacea. Appropriate \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/the-rewired-enterprise-how-five-companies-built-to-outcompete\"\u003echange-management practices around implementation are indispensable\u003c/a\u003e for realizing the potential of tech upgrades.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCarriers and shippers are beginning to adopt these innovations, but there is still value to realize. Companies may struggle to implement these solutions due to a lack of strategic alignment, lack of required capabilities, or insufficient adoption at scale. Companies considering tech adoption could look to these as potential next steps on their journey to reduce waste:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eDevelop strategic alignment.\u003c/strong\u003e This involves an assessment of how much value is at stake and the efficiencies that could be realized through new technology. A key enabler for logistics carriers and shippers may be understanding current operations and then embarking on change management including training personnel and outlining expectations of future operating procedures.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAchieve adoption at scale.\u003c/strong\u003e This may require companies to design and use an implementation roadmap incorporating appropriate change-management practices to guide the tech transformation. A big-bang approach, considering the disparate operations and personnel involved, could be risky. Taking a phased approach, and aligning any changes with the existing operating model, could set tech adoption up to succeed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eBuild capabilities.\u003c/strong\u003e Companies can create a tailored approach, accounting for existing complexities unique to their context. Shippers and carriers may consider setting KPIs for milestones and impact such as reduced dwell time for drivers, or improvement in driver experience.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe problems caused by blind handoffs are worth solving as they can cost the logistics industry up to $95 billion a year in wasted time and resources. Logistics operators have begun exploring tech-based solutions to these problems resulting in a rapidly expanding market for such solutions.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE
